title: True claim about the magnitude of induced current

content.description: The conducting loop shown above is in a region containing two uniform magnetic fields that point out of the page. The magnitude of the field inside the loop is <math alttext="B sub 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the magnitude of the field outside the loop is <math alttext="B sub 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The magnitude of each field is decreasing at a constant rate.
content.question: Which of the following is true of the magnitude of the induced current in the loop while the magnitudes of the fields decrease?

choices.label: It has a constant nonzero value.

content.answer: It has a constant nonzero value.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
